citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility failed to observe a dog in poor dental health. Upon inspection, female Cavalier #7000 was found to have hard,
brown-grey material encasing 60-99% of the crown of the teeth on the upper right and left sides of the mouth. The cheek
teeth (premolars) were also found to be mobile (on both sides). The gum tissue directly above the first premolar on the
right and left sides are red and swollen. On the upper left side of the mouth the gum tissue is receding. The licensee
reports he was not aware of the dog’s dental issues prior to today's inspection. Dental issues can cause pain and distress
to dogs, as well as inhibit their ability to chew properly.
The facility also failed to adequately communicate a medical issue to the Attending Veterinarian (AV). Female Cocker
Spaniel #8721 was observed by the facility to have a swelling on the head a few weeks ago. The swelling is located
approximately 2 inches behind the left eyeball and is approximately 1” x 1” x 1”. It is firm, haired, non-panful, and has a
small scab on the front surface. At the time of the inspection, the facility had not sought out medical guidance by the AV
for this issue. The facility must establish and maintain a program of adequate veterinary care so that the dogs are closely
observed so that their health and wellness can be assessed, and have a mechanism of direct and frequent
communication of any problems then conveyed to the AV. Correct by ensuring a veterinarian is contacted to evaluate both
dogs. Correct by: end of business July 1, 2024.

The facility is not following the Program of Vet Care. Two dogs are not up to date on vaccines. The licensee obtained
these dogs in February 2024.
** Female Cocker Spaniel #6080 has no record of receiving the distemper, parvovirus or rabies vaccines.
** Female Cocker Spaniel #8872 has no record of receiving the distemper or parvovirus vaccines.
Distemper, parvovirus, and rabies are serious and oftentimes life-threatening viruses to dogs. Dogs affected by these
viruses often suffer pain and distress. The Program of Vet Care prescribes for these vaccines to be given yearly. Correct
by following a vaccination plan outlined by the Attending Veterinarian in the Program of Vet Care and approved by the
vaccine manufacturer.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
Correct all directs by the date listed above or prior to the next scheduled re-license inspection, whichever comes first. All
items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 27, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a
valid USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility failed to observe a dog in poor dental health. Upon inspection, female Cavalier #7000 was found to have hard, 
brown-grey material encasing 60-99% of the crown of the teeth on the upper right and left sides of the mouth. The cheek 
teeth (premolars) were also found to be mobile (on both sides). The gum tissue directly above the first premolar on the 
right and left sides are red and swollen. On the upper left side of the mouth the gum tissue is receding. The licensee 
reports he was not aware of the dog’s dental issues prior to today's inspection. Dental issues can cause pain and distress 
to dogs, as well as inhibit their ability to chew properly.  
The facility also failed to adequately communicate a medical issue to the Attending Veterinarian (AV). Female Cocker 
Spaniel #8721 was observed by the facility to have a swelling on the head a few weeks ago. The swelling is located 
approximately 2 inches behind the left eyeball and is approximately 1” x 1” x 1”. It is firm, haired, non-panful, and has a 
small scab on the front surface. At the time of the inspection, the facility had not sought out medical guidance by the AV 
for this issue. The facility must establish and maintain a program of adequate veterinary care so that the dogs are closely 
observed so that their health and wellness can be assessed, and have a mechanism of direct and frequent 
communication of any problems then conveyed to the AV. Correct by ensuring a veterinarian is contacted to evaluate both 
dogs. Correct by: end of business July 1, 2024. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the Program of Vet Care. Two dogs are not up to date on vaccines. The licensee obtained 
these dogs in February 2024.  
** Female Cocker Spaniel #6080 has no record of receiving the distemper, parvovirus or rabies vaccines.  
** Female Cocker Spaniel #8872 has no record of receiving the distemper or parvovirus vaccines.  
Distemper, parvovirus, and rabies are serious and oftentimes life-threatening viruses to dogs. Dogs affected by these 
viruses often suffer pain and distress. The Program of Vet Care prescribes for these vaccines to be given yearly. Correct 
by following a vaccination plan outlined by the Attending Veterinarian in the Program of Vet Care and approved by the 
vaccine manufacturer.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
Correct all directs by the date listed above or prior to the next scheduled re-license inspection, whichever comes first. All 
items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 27, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a 
valid USDA license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
